question_text: Why is an RJ45 connector incompatible with DSL modems, even though both use twisted-pair copper cabling?
answer_options: DSL requires coaxial shielding only supported by RJ11
RJ45 is too narrow to fit the DSL port
RJ11 connectors carry analog signals; RJ45 only supports digital
DSL ports are physically wired for RJ11 pinouts and won’t accept RJ45 plugs
correct_answer: DSL ports are physically wired for RJ11 pinouts and won’t accept RJ45 plugs
explanation: RJ11 and RJ45 use different sizes and pinouts. A DSL modem expects RJ11 wiring; plugging in an RJ45 will not align the signal paths properly.
